title: Highlights From 2019 to Read This Weekend
summary: Resume Subscription. We know there's a lot to read through: Emails, group messages, all those articles you saved and never got around to. And this weekend, The Wall Street Journal is available with free access.

title: The Water's Fine, Mr. Bloomberg
summary: The former New York mayor could be a strong Democratic nominee.. The news that Michael Bloomberg might compete for the Democratic presidential nomination is causing consternation on the political left. But that's all the more reason to welcome his candidacy to challenge a vulnerable President Trump next year.

title: California's Board Diversity Tax
summary: A study finds that a director mandate cost companies $60 billion.. Democrats in California work hard to punish businesses and sometimes they succeed without trying. Consider a 2018 law that imposes gender quotas for boards of public companies based in the state, which a new study finds effectively destroyed $60 billion in wealth over night.

title: Former Brazilian President 'Lula' da Silva Released From Jail
summary: Decision follows Supreme Court ruling that defendants should remain free until all appeals are heard. BRASÍLIA-Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, a standard-bearer of the Latin American left and a political force in Brazil, was released from jail pending appeals Friday, cutting short a long corruption sentence that prevented him from contesting the last presidential election.

title: Loan Investor Owl Rock Sells 20% Stake
summary: Dyal Capital buys minority stake in private-lending business; cash raised will help launch new business development company. Owl Rock Capital Group, one of the fastest-growing firms in one of Wall Street's fastest-growing sectors, is about to get even bigger.

title: Giuliani Associates Urged Ukraine's Prior President to Open Biden Probe
summary: Lev Parnas, Igor Fruman pushed then-president Poroshenko to announce probes in return for U.S. state visit. Months before President Trump pressed Ukraine's newly installed leader to investigate Joe Biden's son and allegations of interference in the 2016 U.S. election, two associates of Rudy Giuliani urged the prior Ukrainian president to announce similar probes in exchange for a state visit to Washington, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Bloomberg Makes Plans to Build Campaign Staff
summary: Billionaire and former New York mayor is likely to further divide bloc of moderate Democratic voters. Billionaire Michael Bloomberg is drawing up a strategy to build campaign staff in states that hold March 2020 primary contests, according to people familiar with his plans, as he leans toward entering the Democratic presidential race despite a difficult path to the nomination.

title: For Airlines, 737 MAX Grounding Will Near One-Year Mark
summary: Southwest, American say they won't offer seats on 737 MAX jets until March. Southwest Airlines Co. and American Airlines Group Inc. said Friday that they won't offer seats on their 737 MAX jets until March, nearly a year after regulators around the world grounded the plane.

title: House Releases Vindman and Hill Testimony
summary: National-security officials say they were taken aback by Sondland's efforts to push Ukraine to launch investigations. WASHINGTON-White House national-security officials testified in the House impeachment inquiry that they were taken aback by the efforts of Ambassador Gordon Sondland to push Ukraine to launch investigations related to U.S. elections, according to transcripts released Friday that also shed light on acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney's purported role in the controversy.

title: Bolton Has More Ukraine Information, His Lawyer Suggests
summary: Attorney's assertion came in a letter disputing that a separate legal case would determine whether Bolton could be compelled to testify in impeachment inquiry. WASHINGTON-Former White House national security adviser John Bolton was involved in meetings and conversations on Ukraine policy that haven't yet come to light, his attorney told the House of Representatives on Friday while disputing that a forthcoming court ruling would determine whether Mr. Bolton must testify in the House impeachment probe.

title: Judge Says U.S. Women's Soccer Team Paid Less Per Game Than Men
summary: Remarks came in procedural ruling granting class-action status to a high-profile pay-discrimination case. The U.S. women's soccer team has been paid less on a per-game basis than the U.S. men's soccer team and suffered from inferior working conditions, said a federal judge who is presiding over the women's ongoing pay-discrimination lawsuit against the U.S. Soccer Federation.

title: 'City on a Hill' Review: Utopia, American-Style
summary: Americans love starting over: 'We shall solve the problem of the city by leaving the city,' Henry Ford said.. Alex Krieger's "City on a Hill: Urban Idealism in America from the Puritans to the Present" provides us with a useful history of the influential ideals-some of them prophetic, some of them unrealistic, and others downright cruel and unjust-that have shaped American cities. Many major figures thought they knew how to make America into a city on a hill, a utopia, a place where we could all live together in bliss and harmony. Their proposals have ranged from Thomas Jefferson's vision of a society of homesteaders to Lyndon Johnson's of newly minted live-work communities; from Ebenezer Howard's garden suburb to George Pullman's company town; from General Motors' magic motorways to Le Corbusier's urban "towers in the park"; from Frederick Law Olmsted's democratizing urban public spaces to the Walt Disney Company's planned community of Celebration, Fla.; from Robert Moses's slum clearance in the name of urban renewal to Bugsy Siegel's casino city in the desert; from William Levitt and his American Dream houses to Jane Jacobs's bustling urban village; and from Daniel 's City Beautiful to Pierre Charles L'Enfant's gracious street plan for Washington, D.C. No dearth of big ideas: But what can we learn from them today?

title: Data-Center Stocks Face Risks After Rally
summary: Whether Equinix, CyrusOne and CoreSite can keep cashing in is unclear. Data-center stocks have benefited handsomely from the boom in cloud computing, but analysts warn that investors shouldn't let past performance cloud their thinking.

title: 'How America's Political Parties Change (and How They Don't)' Review: Prognosticators, Take It Easy
summary: The Democratic Party and the GOP are grand and old because they're resilient and adaptive.. Our political class never seems to tire of bold claims that one or the other of America's two parties is scheduled for demise. In recent years, these prognostications have come mainly from the left. Some, like John B. Judis and Ruy Teixeira's "The Emerging Democratic Majority" (2002), are sophisticated and nuanced, but in the hands of pundits they become little more than self-serving claims to moral superiority and electoral hegemony. The argument at its most typical and simplistic runs as follows: With the rapid increase in the number of nonwhite voters and the increasing acceptance of socially liberal lifestyles, Republican voters will find themselves outnumbered and outmaneuvered.

title: 'The Man Who Saw Everything' Review: A Historian Lost in Time
summary: The author's brief novels are clever, but cleverness for its own sake does not interest her. Being human does.. Deborah Levy wrote her 2018 memoir "The Cost of Living" in a shed at the bottom of a friend's garden, bicycling home each evening to her daughters and her small London flat, divorce still a raw wound. "All writing," she observed at the time, "is about looking and listening and paying attention to the world." The apples crashing down on the shed roof, the freezer in the corner, the spider webs: Each detail, deftly caught, might release a fleeting thought. About gravity, forgery, dogs, dreams. For that garden hut, it turned out, could also accommodate Sigmund Freud, several German philosophers, and quieter guests like Emily Dickinson, all assisting Ms. Levy "to climb in-between the apparent reality of things." Which she has for decades in plays, poetry and numerous works of fiction, among them "Swimming Home" (2011) and "Hot Milk" (2016), slim novels in which weighty matters-perception, reality, heartbreak-become light as air when folded into the layered confection of her prose. The reader too is made buoyant, even a little giddy, by this writer's blend of sinuous ingenuity and deadeye wit.

title: Trump Campaign Saw Roger Stone as Link to WikiLeaks, Bannon Says
summary: Former Trump campaign chairman testifies in Stone's trial on charges of misleading Congress. Former Trump campaign chairman Steve Bannon told jurors Friday he considered Roger Stone to be the campaign's primary conduit for information about WikiLeaks during the 2016 presidential campaign.

title: Administration Issues Plan for Notifying Public of Foreign Election Interference
summary: Plan comes less than a year before 2020 presidential election and faces criticism from some officials. The Trump administration on Friday outlined its plan for issuing public notifications about foreign election interference, but faced swift criticism from some election officials who said it was vague and Democrats who argued it could allow for political influence.

title: PG&E Bankruptcy Protections Could Mean Less Money for Wildfire Victims
summary: Resume Subscription. As many as 100,000 California residents who lost property, jobs and loved ones in fires linked to PG&E Corp. will get their day in court. It will be in bankruptcy court, where rules shield the utility giant from potentially crippling jury payouts.

title: Does Freedom Have a Future in China?
summary: Hong Kong bookseller Lam Wing-kee and mainland artist Jingxiong Guo both endured arrest and now live in exile, but they disagree on the prospects for democratic reform.. Taipei

title: Why Impeachment Will Stay Partisan
summary: The arc of events has been determined by Trump's opponents, who refuse to recognize his legitimacy.. Nobody doubts a Democratic House can produce 218 votes for impeachment. It probably doesn't matter much what the charges are. In some sense, that's where impeachment should land: The charges matter less than whether, under the totality of considerations, a president should be removed before his term ends.

title: I Was a Reverse Commuter Across the Berlin Wall
summary: I went into East Germany to study. I'm lucky the 'People's Police' never suspected otherwise.. On Aug. 13, 1961-a Sunday, chosen because fewer people would be out on the streets-Berliners awoke to find East Berlin being sealed off from West Berlin. In East Berlin the "People's Police" were ripping up streets, piling up asphalt and paving stones to form barricades, driving concrete posts into the ground and erecting barbed wire around them, tearing up the surface of Friedrich-Ebert-Strasse (running along the border with West Berlin to make vehicle traffic impossible, and holding bystanders in check with machine guns. "Factory Fighting Groups," paramilitary units supposedly organized spontaneously to defend "our Socialist Accomplishments," helped the police prevent dissidents from escaping to the West.

title: Higher Education's Enemy Within
summary: An army of nonfaculty staff push for action and social justice at the expense of free inquiry.. American higher education seems to be in a permanent state of crisis. Almost monthly, a federal court has occasion to reprimand some college or university for improperly chilling speech, even as some students continue to complain that campuses are too friendly to the wrong kind of speakers. Many institutions have cut back on faculty hiring, even as the cost of tuition grows. Two basic, and mutually reinforcing, phenomena are behind the chaos on campus.

title: A Football Saturday-and a Cultural Reckoning-in Mid-America
summary: A pregame gathering in a Chicago suburb is like a boisterous church social with beer and brats.. Evanston, Ill.

title: McDonald's, Under Armour, Walt Disney: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. National Beverage Corp.

title: Trump Revs Up Effort to Win Black Vote
summary: President tells Atlanta crowd he has improved African-Americans' employment opportunities, communities. ATLANTA-President Trump took credit for improving African-Americans' lives with more jobs and safer communities and called on them to abandon their traditional support for Democratic candidates at the launch of his initiative to win black voters here Friday.

title: Alibaba Readies Hong Kong Listing Worth Up to $15 Billion
summary: Chinese retail giant expects to seek approval from Hong Kong's stock exchange next week and launch the share sale shortly afterward. Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. is aiming to raise $10 billion to $15 billion with a new listing in Hong Kong this month, according to people familiar with the matter, reviving the planned offering even as the city's political climate remains unstable.

title: Long Win Streak for Tick Index Shows Strength of Stock Rally
summary: Indicator shows a broad contingent of stocks has marched steadily upward for 15 straight trading sessions. The U.S. stock market is in the midst of its most persistent upswing in nearly two years, according to a technical indicator called the New York Stock Exchange Tick Index that is followed by many day traders.

title: Stocks Close at Records as Investors Flee Havens
summary: Investors unraveled bets on traditionally safer investments like U.S. Treasurys and dove back into some of the riskier corners of the stock market this week. U.S. stocks clinched fresh records and government-bond yields notched the biggest weekly gain in a month as investors grew more confident that the economic cycle isn't nearing its end.

title: Eddie Murphy's Raw Capitalism
summary: His new movie is vulgar but it captures the creative spirit of small business.. Eddie Murphy's Netflix movie, "Dolemite Is My Name," is not family entertainment. The language is relentlessly vulgar and the real-life 1970s entertainer Rudy Ray Moore portrayed by Mr. Murphy contributed to a coarsening of culture and the promotion of negative stereotypes. Yet in this story of a washed-up, broke singer who wills himself into the movie industry, we have the rare Hollywood product that captures the spirit of entrepreneurial creativity.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Slip Despite Trump Comments on China Tariffs
summary: Hopes for an agreement that would lower trade barriers have helped improve the outlook for global growth in recent weeks. U.S. government bond prices swung between gains and losses Friday after President Trump said he hadn't agreed to roll back tariffs on China, boosting demand for safe assets.

title: Carlyle's Acosta Strikes Creditor Deal For Prepackaged Bankruptcy
summary: Marketing services firm reaches agreement with creditors to eliminate all $3 billion of its debt through chapter 11. Acosta Inc., a Carlyle Group LP -owned marketing firm that has struggled with customer losses and changing consumer tastes, has reached an agreement with creditors to eliminate all $3 billion of its debt through a chapter 11 filing.

title: Crude Rally Fades on Chinese Oil Import Record
summary: Report deflates some optimism that a detente in U.S.-China trade war would boost oil demand. A nascent rally in oil prices fizzled on Friday after Chinese customs data showed the country imported more crude in October than ever before, despite the continuing trade friction with the U.S.

title: Jury Finds Former Alstom Executive Guilty of Foreign Bribery
summary: Trial of Lawrence Hoskins tested reach of U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. NEW HAVEN, Conn.-A jury found a former Alstom SA executive guilty of helping orchestrate a bribery scheme in Indonesia, a verdict that reinforces the reach of a U.S. law prohibiting bribes to foreign government officials.

title: McDonald's Began Probe of CEO's Relationship Three Weeks Ago
summary: Relationship led to Steve Easterbrook's firing by burger giant. McDonald's Corp., which fired its chief executive last week over a consensual relationship with a female employee, first learned of the matter roughly three weeks ago, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: She Climbed Kilimanjaro. But the Real Achievement: Keeping Her Phone Alive.
summary: Extreme conditions require unusual measures to preserve gadgets and get online; 756 messages that won't open. MOUNT KILIMANJARO-At 13,800 feet on Africa's highest mountain, as the nighttime temperature dipped and I drew my hot-water bottle closer, the following thoughts occurred in quick succession:

title: Executives Convicted in Long-Running Italian Banking Scandal
summary: Current and ex-executives of Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, Deutsche Bank and Nomura draw suspended sentences. A Milan court on Friday convicted 13 former and current executives of Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA, Deutsche Bank AG and Nomura International PLC of a number financial crimes, in a long-running judicial saga tied to losses at the troubled Italian bank.

title: Chicago Turns to Former LAPD Chief as Interim Police Superintendent
summary: Resume Subscription. CHICAGO-Chicago's mayor on Friday said she would appoint the recently retired chief of the Los Angeles Police Department as interim chief while the city searches for a successor to Superintendent Eddie Johnson.

title: Plastics Still Matter to Payments
summary: For all the publicity on digital payments, most consumers still rely on good old plastic cards to transact. And someone has to make that plastic card, and someone has to sell it.. Payments company Fiserv has one word for fintech analysts. Are you listening? Plastics.

title: Trump Supports Raising E-Cigarette Purchase Age to 21
summary: President says move aimed at curbing teen use as administration considers limits on e-cigarette flavors. President Trump is supporting a move to raise the minimum purchase age for e-cigarettes nationwide to 21 from 18 in an effort aimed at curbing teenage vaping.

title: India Braces for Ruling on Ancient Hindu-Muslim Dispute
summary: Resume Subscription. AYODHYA, India-This ancient city has long been the center of a struggle for the soul of India.

title: The Dark Originality of Goya
summary: The Spanish artist's rarely exhibited drawings document a society torn by war.. The work of Spanish artist Francisco de Goya seems to span several eras. Trained in the stiff rigors of 18th-century neoclassicism, Goya (1746-1828) went on to inspire 19th-century realists and 20th-century surrealists. The late critic Robert Hughes regarded Goya as "the last Old Master and the first Modernist," and the digital age has done nothing to dim his relevance.

title: Game Makers Expect to Ring in Holidays With Strong Digital Sales
summary: Makers organizing special events inside blockbusters, adding features to keep players engaged. Videogame companies aim to lean further on high-margin digital sales this holiday season, as more consumers ditch discs for downloads and publishers find creative ways to generate revenue from their biggest hits long after release.

title: House Freedom Caucus Emerges as Trump's Main Defender
summary: Group of conservative Republicans who once toppled party leadership finds new role in impeachment probe. WASHINGTON-The House Freedom Caucus rose to prominence as a rebellious band of about three dozen Republican lawmakers willing to buck their party establishment to tank legislation-or even topple House speakers-they deemed insufficiently conservative. Now the group has embraced a new role: President Trump's de facto defense team in the impeachment investigation on Capitol Hill.

title: Consumers Could Spread Some Holiday Cheer
summary: Americans' moods have dimmed, but the economy is still providing them with the wherewithal to spend. Americans aren't as chipper heading into the holidays as they were last year. That may not mean they are unwilling to spend, though.

title: The New Hot Job: Real-Time Password Manager
summary: Who couldn't use 24/7 live human help to recall how to log in?. People often wonder how the unemployment rate can remain so low in an era when manufacturing jobs have all but disappeared. Where are all these new jobs coming from?

title: Fed's Daly: Fed Cannot Ignore What Climate Change Is Doing to Economy
summary: Reserve Bank of San Francisco president says addressing the issue is part of 'core responsibilities'. Fed officials increasingly believe climate-change issues are factors the U.S. central bank must consider when weighing the outlook for the economy and watching over banks.

title: Impeachment Inquiry Becomes Reality TV
summary: Nancy Pelosi knows a partisan process will go nowhere in the Senate and is unlikely to change the minds of swing voters, but she may not care as long as she brands Mr. Trump with a scarlet I and an appreciative Democratic base gets even more charged up for next year's showdown.. Kimberley Strassel argues that Democrats' refusal to open up the impeachment process and potentially gain Republican votes gave the GOP a powerful case against the proceedings ("A Partisan Impeachment Vote," Potomac Watch, Nov. 1). Your same-day editorial "Defining Impeachment Down" points out that the Democrats' impeachment resolution "essentially keeps Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff in charge and able to continue his secret hearings as long as he wants." You suspect that Speaker Nancy Pelosi knows that a partisan process will go nowhere in the Senate and is unlikely to change the minds of swing voters, but she may not care as long as she brands Mr. Trump with a scarlet I and an appreciative Democratic base gets even more charged up for next year's showdown.

title: Appeasement Helped Hitler, but the RAF, Too
summary: As Mr. Roberts reports, it was the Germans "who used the extra year between Munich and the outbreak of war far better than the Western powers.". Perhaps the greatest contribution of "Appeasement" by Tim Bouverie, as reviewed by Andrew Roberts (Books, Nov. 2), is the refutation of the last argument of the lonely few who still defend the Munich Agreement of 1938-that selling out Czech sovereignty to appease Adolf Hitler gave Britain an additional year to prepare for war.

title: The Intoxication of Doing Business With the Chinese
summary: Remaining sober required a creative solution.. The article about Chinese Moutai brought back many happy memories ("Popular Liquor Is Hard to Buy, Tough to Swallow," Page One, Nov. 1). In the 1990s I presided over my employer's joint venture in China. My responsibilities included numerous banquets with our Chinese partners. Surviving multiple rounds of Moutai while remaining sober required a creative solution: Drain the cup; hold it upside down over your head to prove it's empty; then wipe your mouth with a napkin, while deftly spitting all of the beverage into said napkin. After that, keep your napkin away from open flames for the rest of the evening. Gan bei (dry cup), indeed!

title: Beards Make Little Real Difference in Modern War
summary: I deployed to Afghanistan for the better part of a year-my gas mask stored safely in my foot locker the entire time, far from my Apache helicopter.. With respect to Lt. Col. Bill Hestir ("Grant and Lee's Beards Never Saw Gas Masks," Letters, Nov 2): I deployed to Afghanistan for the better part of a year-my gas mask stored safely in my foot locker the entire time, far from my Apache helicopter. A beard would have made no difference one way or the other. There is great value in our military projecting a professional image, but also great value lost in the service going deliberately out of its way to have its members look distinctly different than the society it serves.

title: Could Electric Vehicles Really Help Prevent Forest Fires?
summary: If you think the increased risk of power outages due to disasters argues against the purchase of an electric vehicle, you'd be wrong, says Dan Neil. Here's why EVs might actually be your best option during emergencies. I LIVE IN NORTH CAROLINA now, but I feel for my old friends in California, some several million of them. Both states, East and West coasts, are manifesting the effects of climate change. Drought and hurricane, fire and water.

title: The Right Bicycles for an Epic Ride Across America
summary: New bikes and better equipment are making cross-country cycling journeys easier for novice riders. A FRIEND, now in his 60s, still loves to revel in his memories of twice biking across the U.S. as a college student more than four decades ago. He set out the first time laden with a tent, sleeping bag, gear, dry foods and water. The second trek he rolled off casually, with $96 tucked in a sock. He'd learned on the first outing that by stringing his route through college towns, he could always find a grad student to feed him, love him and send him off. Hey, it was the 1970s.

title: The Power of Combining 5G and AI
summary: Putting the two technologies together will change everything from drug making to brewing beer. The convergence of artificial intelligence with internet-connected machines and superfast 5G wireless networks is opening possibilities across the planet-and even in outer space.

title: Boston Celtic Enes Kanter Calls Foul on Repression in Turkey
summary: The outspoken NBA center has been labeled a 'terrorist' by his native country's government for his association with an exiled cleric. Enes Kanter, the Boston Celtics' new center, isn't the kind of athlete who is content to shut up and play. When LeBron James seemingly sought to placate China, chiding Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey for a tweet supporting protesters in Hong Kong, Mr. Kanter tweeted, "Wow dude," accompanied by a hand-to-face emoji. For good measure, he added "SMH" (shaking my head) and a barfing emoji. Last week, Mr. Kanter took to Twitter again to lambaste Rep. Ilhan Omar (D., Minn.) for voting against a bill to place economic sanctions on Turkey for its military offensive against Kurdish forces in northern Syria.

title: Trump Says U.S. Hasn't Yet Agreed to Ease China Tariffs
summary: President disputes earlier statement from China's Commerce Ministry that tariff relief would be part of the first phase of a trade accord. WASHINGTON-President Trump on Friday disputed China's assertion that the two countries had agreed to roll back tariffs as part of an interim trade accord, but he also said progress was being made toward resolving the long-running trade war.

title: Death of a Student Riles Protesters, Puts Hong Kong on Alert
summary: Circumstances of the death are unclear but people are demanding an investigation of police actions; incident will likely inflame tensions in the city. HONG KONG-A university student died after being comatose for days from injuries sustained near the scene of a clash between police and protesters, sparking fresh anger that has fueled antigovernment demonstrations and unrest for five months.

title: Evoking an Exotic World
summary: Delacroix's 'Women of Algiers in Their Apartment,' a newly discovered early version of a famed canvas, offers insight into his methods and fascinations.. The surprising announcement in June that an important painting by the French artist Eugène Delacroix (1798-1863) had been found after almost 170 years left many in the art world skeptical. A new entry into the Romantic painter's well-known and documented canon-which, as witnessed in 2018 retrospectives in Paris and New York, continues to solicit widespread scholarly and popular attention-seemed unlikely. In front of the jewel-like canvas in question, however, now at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, any doubts as to its authenticity disappear. Delacroix's "Women of Algiers in Their Apartment" (c. 1832-34), an early, upright variant of a larger painting in the Louvre, offers vital insights into the artist's methods, and a window into his consuming fascination with the world he discovered on a formative trip to North Africa. Above all, the Houston canvas-which measures about 18 by 15 inches, is in pristine condition, and exhibits the painter's unmistakable palette and lush, tremulous touch-is absolutely beautiful.

title: Fed's Brainard Says Climate Change Might Have Implications for Neutral Interest Rate
summary: Federal Reserve governor cited research showing more-frequent heat waves could affect economic output and labor productivity. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve governor Lael Brainard said the central bank is ramping up its efforts to understand the implications of climate change for monetary policy and noted that the phenomenon may have consequences for interest rates.

title: Quantum Computing Holds Promise for Banks, Executives Say
summary: 'You could argue that finance has got the shortest path to impact,' says Goldman's head of research-and-development engineering. BROOKLYN, N.Y.-When quantum computing hits the market, the financial-services industry could be the first to benefit, a Goldman Sachs Group Inc. executive said at a quantum-computing panel event.

title: U.S.-China Trade Talks Face Another Hurdle: Where to Sign the Deal
summary: Timing and political optics factor in; 'If they think Trump wants it in Iowa, that's a bargaining chip'. WASHINGTON-The U.S. and China are grappling with a dual challenge on trade: wrapping up an interim deal, and solving the logistical puzzle of getting President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping in the same place to sign it.

title: Blackstone Takes Controlling Stake in Owner of Dating App Bumble
summary: MagicLab founder Andrey Andreev to sell his stake, hand CEO role to Bumble founder Whitney Wolfe Herd. Blackstone Group Inc. is taking a majority stake in the owner of dating app Bumble as part of the private-equity giant's broader push to invest more in fast-growing companies.

title: 'Herself Alone' Review: No Woman Is an Island
summary: In 1987, Margaret Thatcher won a landslide third term as prime minister of the U.K.. Beneath the sheen of triumph, however, her administration would be beset by decay.. The day before the Conservative Party leadership election in November 1990, a government minister, Alan Clark, knocked at the office door of Peter Morrison, a Conservative member of Parliament and Margaret Thatcher's campaign manager. Receiving no answer, Clark tried the handle and found Morrison asleep in a chair, snoring. "This was ten minutes past three in the afternoon of the most critical day of the whole election," Clark wrote in his diary. "It can't really be as bad as this can it?" In fact, it was worse. Within days Thatcher would be out-Britain's longest serving prime minister of the modern era ousted in what she herself would describe as a cabinet coup.

title: Five Best: Robert Jay Lifton on Worlds Destroyed
summary: The author, most recently, of 'Losing Reality: On Cults, Cultism, and the Mindset of Political and Religious Zealotry' selects books on the aftermath of cataclysm.. By Rudolf Höss (1959)

title: 'Walter Ralegh: Architect of Empire' Review: The Enlightened Adventurer
summary: Sir Walter Ralegh was a swashbuckling pirate, poet, colonizer and courtier who founded a doomed settlement on the North Carolina coast and named a swath of territory 'Virginia' in honor of his royal patron.. If Americans know of Sir Walter Ralegh today, it is as the founder of the "Lost Colony" of Roanoke, which disappeared without a trace a few years after it was established on the North Carolina coast. Some, perhaps, associate him with his quixotic quest for the golden city of "El Dorado" in the South American jungle. But such wispy associations fail to do justice to the colonial visionary, swashbuckling pirate, poet, courtier and alleged traitor whom Alan Gallay has vividly conjured in "Walter Ralegh: Architect of Empire," a richly researched and engagingly written biography.

title: Fiction: The Barn Door, Closed Too Late
summary: A thief, the woman who loves him, and the fall guy for their restless yearnings.. 'Horses don't honor your hopes for them," a neighbor tells Muriel, the protagonist of Shannon Pufahl's debut, "On Swift Horses" (Riverhead, 306 pages, $27), as they search for a runaway steed. The same could be said for Muriel's prodigal brother-in-law, Julius. The year is 1957 and Muriel and her husband, Lee, have bought a plot in a valley in Southern California where, according to the brothers' plan, Julius is supposed to join them to help work the farm. But the man visits just once, then steals their spending money and, like the horse, bolts in the dead of night.

title: Mysteries: The Riot Inside Them
summary: An ambitious novel that toggles between the present day and the early 1990s to depict two Los Angeles families-one Korean-American, the other African-American-linked by a tragic death.. Steph Cha's latest novel, "Your House Will Pay" (Ecco, 304 pages, $26.99), is ambitious, accomplished and remarkably compelling. Set in Southern California, the work takes place mostly in the present but also features sections from the early 1990s. It focuses on the families of Shawn Matthews, a 41-year-old African-American, and Grace Park, the daughter of Korean immigrants.

title: Children's Books: A New Breed of Tales About a Child's Best Friend
summary: To be a kid is to dream sweet dreams of dogs.. If you were to devise a pie chart showing the contents of a typical child's daydreams, there's a good chance that the largest slice would be labeled "dog." Yearning for a dog, dreaming of a dog, scheming to overcome parental resistance to a dog: For many kids-and if there's one in your household, you know it-these are prime preoccupations. Happily for them, it's been a big year for books on a canine theme.

title: 'The Letters of Cole Porter' Review: Delightful, Delicious, Diligent
summary: Cole Porter's breezy style was the result of extraordinarily hard work. The public thought him a flâneur, but he was actually a bit of a grind.. In 1908, a prep-school principal grew worried enough about one of his charges, a bright boy of 17, to contact the student's mother. His concern was sincere, though its cause was unusual: "Do you think that one may be too popular?"

title: Prosecutors Charge N.Y. Firm With Selling Banned Chinese Gear to U.S. Military
summary: U.S. buyers believed they were getting American-made night-vision cameras and other products but they were in fact made in China. In August 2018, a service member at a U.S. Air Force base noticed something unusual about a new body camera there: Chinese characters appeared on its built-in screen, including what turned out to be the logo for China's domestic-security agency.

title: 'Mud and Stars' Review: On the Road With Pushkin
summary: A literary jaunt through the land of Pushkin and Tolstoy takes Sara Wheeler to such far corners of Russia as a restaurant in the frozen northeast where the teaspoons have holes to discourage thieves.. Like so many travelers from the 16th century on, Sara Wheeler set out to find the real Russia-"a Russia not in the news-a Russia of common humanity and daily struggles." Her guides were the great Russian writers of the Golden Age, from Pushkin to Chekhov. She read their works and toured the places they lived and described.

title: Don't Hold Your Breath Waiting for Oil Companies to Turn Green
summary: One day there may be a windmill on every corner and a solar panel on every roof. That day isn't coming any time soon.. At first glance, Saudi Aramco's plans for an enormous December IPO might well suggest the future of Big Oil is robust. Aramco earns more than Amazon.com Inc., Apple Inc. and Microsoft Corp. combined; its market value is expected in the $1.5 trillion to $2 trillion range.

title: The Ordinary People Who Brought Down the Berlin Wall
summary: On Nov. 9, 1989, many otherwise unremarkable East Germans made world history-often largely by accident. On the evening of Nov. 9, 1989, an unremarkable East German functionary named Günter Schabowski bungled an assignment-and accidentally helped bring down the Berlin Wall. A Politburo member, Schabowski had ended up with a thankless job: trying to mollify the vast, growing crowds of East Berliners who had been inspired by Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's promises of glasnost (or "openness") and reform. By early November 1989, protests numbering in the hundreds of thousands were overwhelming communist East Germany.

title: 'Cyrano' Review: Sorry, Wrong Numbers
summary: Everything about this musical version of Edmond de Rostand's tale is successful, except for the songs.

Spencer, resigned, saying: "The job is no longer any fun."

summary: Thirty years after the Berlin Wall fell, the euphoria in the former Soviet bloc has dimmed, but the blessings of liberty remain.. Three decades is generally enough time for the changing perspective of history to make a mockery of our early reading of epochal events.

summary: Security researchers agree that for most people, adding text-message authentication is a big step up from only using a password, but that can leave you open to a relatively new attack called SIM swapping. His mobile phone lost its signal.

summary: Despite a format change, the No. 1 seeds in each conference both failed to reach the MLS Cup. title: What Does It Take to Have a Custom Library?
summary: Three book dealers who source vintage volumes and create bespoke book collections for high-profile clients share trade tips and secrets. In the late 1980s and early 1990s, Kinsey Marable was working as a banker at Goldman Sachs, spending a week out of every month in London. "Walking around there, I found out-of-print-book shops, a phenomenon I'd never really seen before," he recalls. "It really captured me." Marable left his finance job in 1992, subsequently becoming a curator of private libraries, with clients such as Donna Karan, Tory Burch and Oprah Winfrey, for whom he put together a library of first-edition Pulitzer-winning fiction. Now based out of a farm in Charlottesville, Virginia, the 63-year-old Marable rejects current trends like color-coordinating books on the shelf or displaying volumes backward so the spines are hidden. As far as the literature he selects goes, it doesn't necessarily have to be rare. "I want all the libraries to have a high level of integrity," Marable says. "They're going to be books that I personally would be happy to have. It gets very personal." privatelibraries.com

title: Contributors to the 2019 Innovators Issue of WSJ. Magazine
summary: Author Roxane Gay, director-photographer Yorgos Lanthimos and others featured in 2019's Innovators issue.. "My first thought was that I was going to have to employ all my self-control to not ask her about Beyoncé," says Gay, referencing Matsoukas's music-video collaborations with the star. "In all seriousness, I was incredibly excited to speak with her, because she is so creative and interesting." title: Targeting Mark Zuckerberg
summary: The avalanche of attacks against Facebook's speech policy continues.. Perhaps the most important political divide in our polarized times isn't between those who support Donald Trump and those who oppose him. It's between those who think American values like free expression still matter and those who think Mr. Trump's Presidency is a license to dispense with them.

title: Meritocracy's Waterloo?
summary: The University of California may scrap admissions testing.. Social-justice organizations last week threatened the University of California with a lawsuit unless it halts the use of standardized testing in admissions, claiming the tests discriminate against minorities. Who knows what success they may have before a sympathetic judge. But the issue may be settled sooner as the political mood in the UC moves against testing. This shift could have baleful nationwide consequences.

title: Parody of a Climate Trial
summary: After three years, the New York AG drops two charges against Exxon.. Well, that was anti-climactic. New York's attorney general spent the past three weeks in state court trying to prove that Exxon Mobil deceived investors with its climate-change disclosures. The trial ended this week with the AG dropping two charges of fraud, proving the lawsuit's dirty political provenance.
